John Arrowwood wrote:

>
>What's unfortunate is that when it died, the new topology created to replace 
>it wasn't based on the one that died.
>
Normally this is desired behaviour. If a species hasn't improved for 
some time then that can be taken as an indication that the species 
represents a local optimum and therefore should be abandoned. If you 
want to give the species more of a chance then it's probbaly more valid 
to increase the time to species death.

Colin.
